Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2013 11:29AM RetrieverMomNancy wrote: My latest PET showed a small progression in my hips so my Oncologist suggested estrogen therapy as an option. I've gone through the typical hormonals and we talked about staying on Aromasin/Afinitor, moving on to another chemo, or trying 6mg of Estradiol daily. He thinks the timing for the third option is good because I've been on an anti-estrogen drug for a long time so if we give the cancer what it wants (estrogen) it will gorge itself and explode and die. The secondary hope is that the remaining cells may be sensitive to the anti-estrogen drugs again. Goodbye wrinkles...hello libido! I have high hopes this will work for six months or more! I'd be interested in hearing from others who have tried this treatment. Nancy
Posts.Title: Treating ER+ with estrogen when anti-hormonals faili? marymoir RetrieverMomNancy

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2009 06:49AM RetrieverMomNancy wrote: Nanlinda, Sorry you have to join us, but you'll find this a great group of strong women. I was dx in Aug. of 07 and did 6 rounds of TAC. After a mast and radiation I was pretty much clean from June until my TMs jumped in Sept. A PET showed mets to the spine in a couple of places (although I had no symptoms, felt great and as you say, had stopped think about cancer 24/7. I started Taxol, Avastin and Zometa in Sept, so I'll be done with the Taxol in March. I'm just now starting to think about "what's next?". I think I'll be on the Avastin and Zometa long term, but I'm expecting a chemo break. I think we'll follow things closely with TM tests every couple of months and PETs. My understanding is that my cancer may stay at bay for several years, but I may be kidding myself. My onc was quick to say that he has one similar gal who is 16 years out and one who is 18 years out...and they didn't have the advantages I have early on. He's very positive about my long term prognosis and that really helps my confidence. I have high hopes for many years of high quality of life time! I don't want to look back on this time as my lost years and if I don't have a lot of years left, I sure don't want to waste a day! Like you, I was a lurker on the bc boards during my original treatment, but once I became a stage IV gal and saw all of the support from the wonderful women on the mets board I finally joined and started posting. Hugs and prayers to you. Nancy
Posts.Title: Let me introduce myself. Nanalinda LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2009 08:26AM RetrieverMomNancy wrote: Why can't you get chemo through a vein in your arm? I know it's not a good long term solution, but once or twice shouldn't hurt. I'm also not sure why they'd take out the port, why not just treat the clot with blood thinners? Good luck to you. By the way, I personally think your Dr. is a jerk for giving you such absolute timeframes! None of us have an expiration date tatooed on our butts! Nancy
Posts.Title: Urgent: Advice Needed for Port clot and canceled chemo GracePang GracePang

Posts.Content: May 13, 2011 08:21AM RetrieverMomNancy wrote: PJB, I've been on a low dose of a diuretic for a couple years now and it helps to keep the swelling down. I think it's pretty benign in terms of interacting with other meds and should give you some relief. Just don't plan on any long distance drives within the first couple of hour of taking the pills! The word urgency will have a new definition for you! Nancy
Posts.Title: Anyone have to take diuretic while on chemo? PJB PJB

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2011 07:16AM RetrieverMomNancy wrote: Marsha, Think about getting a pair of compression knee-hi hose to wear on the flight. Might help keep the swelling under control. Also, get up and walk around every hour or so. Have fun! Nancy
Posts.Title: Dodged the bullet mthomp2020 MCTHO

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2010 10:29AM RetrieverMomNancy wrote: Go for it!!! You have two wigs that look good and that will really help your spirits as you travel and see a lot of people you know. You can be in control at this point and I think it helps emotionally. Good luck to you. Nancy
Posts.Title: Shaving my head today lorrhaw dreamwriter

Posts.Content: May 1, 2013 05:55AM RetrieverMomNancy wrote: I had a PE four years ago while on Avastin and Fasodex, so I'm on Warfarin and have some experience in this area. I did lovenox shots until reaching my therapeutic range and one other time when my INR was low, but there's no way I'd want to do it long term. Frapp, you might want to talk to your family doc about taking over INR management. I talked my way into getting a home monitor (easy-peazy to use) and it's made my life easier because I don't have to go in for blood draws. I go months when I'm in range and only have to test every 10 to 14 days. The wacky times coincide with changes in meds. We really had to watch it when I went on Xeloda, but finally got it under control.
Posts.Title: Blood clots or DVT's K-Lo gonegirl

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2011 05:43AM RetrieverMomNancy wrote: Jennifer, I hope you're feeling better and will consider getting hgb "help" if you still feel wiped out. Good to hear the you and your DH worked things out. It's taken me a few years, but I guess I give my DH a bit of a break because I can only imagine how helpless and frightened he feels. I'm lucky and feel normal (for a 55 year old rubenesque gal) most of the time, but he doesn't know that unless I'm sitting in front of him. I suspect his fears go up every day I head out of the driveway and off to work. Makes him nuts when I have out of town business travel. We'll go for weeks when just about every conversation starts with him asking "how are your hands, how are your feet, do you have diarrhea, what color is your urine?" Geeze, he's my lover in addition to being my husband and this is gross! When I'm having problems I try to remind myself that I'm feeling lousy because of a side effect from the tx, as opposed to the cancer itself. It makes it a little less scary and reminds me that I should take advantage of everything offered that will lessen the SEs. Hope you're having a nice weekend. Good luck to you. Nancy
Posts.Title: Low Hgb, lots of tears, just so tired Honeybear Heidihill

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2010 08:39PM retrievermom wrote: Judy, Many aspects of your experience mirror my own first round, and my own feelings that I hadn't been told everything I would have liked.  I did not expect the extreme constipation at all, the stomach cramps, the stuffy head, and the inability to sleep (I can't take sleep aids, and things like benedryl hype me up instead of making me sleepy).  I wasn't able to eat dinner for a week, because my intestinal problems would worsen in the evening.  Then, out of the blue, my day 7 was so much better I couldn't believe it.  This after a horrid day 6 that left me an emotional wreck.  Day 8 I told my husband we were going out to dinner; I wasn't going to miss the opportunity.  Day 9 (today) was fine in the morning, a crash in the afternoon, and other than sore mouth, ok tonight.  I am enjoying the let-up for however long it lasts. When I broke down the other night (as soon as my husband got home), I got ranting about Pink Warriors and "positive thinking."  Barbara Ehrenreich has a new book out about America's fixation on positive thinking.  The first chapter is on bc.  Crankiness has its place.  And sorrow. I wish you all some good days that help make the bad days more bearable.
Posts.Title: After 1st T/C chemo: What nobody tells you JudyM mslrg

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2013 04:07AM RetrieverMomNancy wrote: 175! Read almost daily but don't post often. Great idea Mrs M.
Posts.Title: How Many Are We? DivineMrsM kt1966

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2008 09:36AM RetrieverMomNancy wrote: Naomi, You are a human being, not a statistic! I think once we're out of the 95%+ long term survival stat, all that looking at the numbers does is scare us. Each person's journey is different. Even though I'd heard the words "high chance for recurrence" when my onc and surgeon were debating lumpectomy vs mast. last Feb. (after neo-adj TAC) it didn't sink in. No one was more surprised than me when Arimidex failed and bone mets sprouted in less than a year. I have faith that my new tx will work and if it doesn't, there's always plan B! My onc and chemo nurses all say that attitude is everything. Try to avoid dwelling on the "what if" and live your life to its fullest. Nancy
Posts.Title: 80 % chance of it coming back!!! Naomi browneyes2323

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2010 04:03AM retrievermom wrote: Raili, I am preparing for radiation treatments, too.  I realize my feelings about male docs and techs are different from yours, but I respect your feelings and hear your anxiety.  I live in an area where the women I work with are of a faith group different from mine.  A co-worker said her husband strongly objected to other men handling her breast during treatment.  Caregivers respected his feelings, but I suspect it was because they were of the same faith.  Whatever the root cause of your concerns, find someone involved in your care who will listen to you and take you seriously.   I'm anxious about the radiation as well, because of the unknown.  Your "sisters" care.
Posts.Title: Does someone literally have to touch your breast every day?? Raili Sido

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2009 09:44AM RetrieverMomNancy wrote: The first thing my wonderful onc said when I was dx with bone mets in Sept. 08  was...hey, I've got a gal who is 16 years out and a gal who is 18 years out with basically the same thing you have AND THEY DIDN'T HAVE THE EARLY ADVANTAGE OF THE DRUGS AVAILABLE TO YOU! It changed my whole way of looking at things. Earlier this week my 6 mo. post chemo PET came back with mets showing up in the spine again, so I'm back on Taxol, but I looked him in the eyes and said...am I crazy for thinking I can live another 20 or 30 years...and he said NO! I don't know how many gals are out there with stage IV for 10 or 20 years, but I think there are quite a few. I like to daydream about how many there could be and the chance that many of them are enjoying a great QOL and they don't have the need for the support of boards like this. I have high hopes that more and more of us will still be around for many, many years and I'm thankful for the support of all of you strong women on the stage IV board! Nancy
Posts.Title: Anyone 10 or 20 year surviror at this Stage TLF Padiddle

Posts.Content: May 12, 2010 10:07PM retrievermom wrote: Daniela:  I did not understand my path report, so I asked questions about it.  I didn't understand the ramifications of recurrence, either.  I asked about how chemo works, why my onc chose 4 rounds rather than 6, and why he recommended the type of chemo regimen.  Folks can give you a rough idea of SEs, but each person responds so individually, they can't pinpoint what your experience will be.  The information packets and what the onc tells you may feel overwhelming.  Give yourself time to digest, and ask more questions as they come up through the process.
Posts.Title: Question for oncologist - help Del9 marcy4

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2010 03:25PM retrievermom wrote: My surgeon didn't seem to think I needed chemo, but wanted me to talk to the oncologist, "the expert," in her words.  All along, I've been thinking that I'm waiting to start radiation.  Adding the possibiiity of chemo, but seeing the radiation onc first confuses me.  A friend said the issue of chemo was raised because I'm estrogen negative.  My surgeon said it was raised because the cancer had moved beyond the duct.
Posts.Title: Wanting to chicken out of radiation... lotstolivefor helena1018

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2010 05:29AM retrievermom wrote: Last month, as I flew out of Salt Lake, the agent let us know which line was for the fully body scanner machine; that was the way by which travelers could opt in or out.  As someone with a total hip, I have been patted down using the old method for years.  I completely understand the frustration over the elderly man being asked to remove his prothesis.  I've had my crutches taken and asked if I could walk through the scanner without them; "do you need these to walk?"  I was asked.  This past trip, I opted for the full scan so they could see what's inside me--rods, joint, clips--and avoid the rub down.  Coming back, from DCA, I was wanded.  When asked to step aside and wait for an agent, I look around and see my fellow potential terrorists--almost all of them middle aged or older, probably with hip and knee replacements.  These are folks who cannot stand on one leg and hold the other in the air.  GEEESH!  There are other ways to accomplish the goal.
Posts.Title: Full body scanners and foobs OLBinNJ Leah_S

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2010 09:12PM RetrieverMomNancy wrote: Diane, There's no doubt, losing your hair is the pits. I've gone back and forth between chemo and hormonals for the past three years and lost my hair every fall. I guess I'm lucky because I've been able to avoid wigs during the summer. I just had another progression, so it's back to chemo again, but this time I'm doing Xeloda and hair loss isn't a big SE. I understand there are other maintenence chemos that aren't hard on the hair. I'm more than willing to lose my hair again (and again, and again) if we can find txs that keep the beast at bay, but it's nice to have something on top to run my fingers through. Find a wig you love, that makes you look cute as a bug's ear! Good luck to you. Nancy P.S. During one of my bald phases I was on a business trip -- getting ready in the morning -- had my makeup on, gold hoop earings on when I walked into the bathroom. I looked up and was shocked to see Mr. Clean staring back at me from the mirror! Cracked me up for the rest of the day! Does anyone else look like Mr. Clean?

My best wishes and prayers go out to her family and friends and all of us who will miss her. Nancy

Posts.Content: May 26, 2011 04:57PM RetrieverMomNancy wrote: Susan, My original oncologist sold his practice almost exactly a year ago and I feel your pain. It was really hard because none of the nurses and familiar faces went with the new oncology practice. I think I broke out in tears at least once every visit for about three months. Eventually the new faces started looking familiar and relationships grew. My new onc understands that we're looking at a 10 to 20 year plan - with the option of renegotiating. We have nice personal conversations that take up most of the visit and I've gone from extensive bones mets and a few liver mets last summer to NED this month! It's tough at the start, but you never know what a lovely new relationship may be formed. Good luck to you.  Nancy

Posts.Title: Something positive Chickadee exbrnxgrl

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2009 03:26PM RetrieverMomNancy wrote: Donna, I did 6 cycles of Taxol last fall for bone mets and found it pretty darn easy to handle. My hair thinned to the point that I did wear a wig in the cold months, but my eyebrows and lashes stayed pretty much intact. I had some tingling in my left hand and toes, but B6 kept in from getting too bad. The Taxol did a bang up job and I was NED after treatment. When my 6 month post chemo PET this Sept. showed a return of mets to the spine we jumped right back in on the Taxol again. I've finished two cycles and although pretty thin, my hair is hanging in there! I'm doing three weeks on and one week off. Feeling just dandy and back to working out four or five days a week. Good luck to you! Nancy
Posts.Title: PET/CT scan results in. Time for a wig! donnabee RobinWendy

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2012 08:36AM RetrieverMomNancy wrote: Pat, I'm a pretty busty gal too and have been uni-boobed since Feb. 2008. I use a foob most of the time. It's actually about the same weight as the real one, so it helps keep me "even" and I avoid back problems. I'm too cheap for fancy mast. bras, so I buy what I've always liked, keep my foob in the little soft bag they supplied and tuck it in the bra. My DS assures me it looks okay (she loves me and will let me know if I look goofy!). The bags are washable and I have a few. I actually have a "swim foob" too. I'm in the water a lot and I was afraid I would wreck my foob. The swim version was much cheaper and I don't regret my purchase. I guess you could say, all together, I have a pair and a spare. I have to admit that I bought a size (or 2) too small (because I'm always going to lose weight) and now I sometimes wish I wouldn't have been so vain - or unrealistic. Good luck to you. Nancy
Posts.Title: Sitting at DF waiting for results Frapp Frapp

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2010 01:07AM RetrieverMomNancy wrote: I know you didn't ask about Xeloda, but I had to chime in. If you get to the point that Xeloda is your best option, please note that the Coumadin issue can be managed. I'm on Coumadin for a PE too and my numbers jumped like crazy when I first started on Xeloda in late August- from 1.2. to 8.8! We've gotten it under control for the past month or more. I recently was approved for a home PT/INR monitor through my insurance company and I'm looking forward to not having to go in for frequent blood draws. My husband created a wonderful graph that shows when I'm on and off Xeloda, my PT/INR results and the amount of Coumadin I take. The doctor's office actually used it to help figure out how much Coumadin I should take at different times. (He's a retired engineer, so he likes this sort of thing.) I too think you should be able to find a local onc who can work with the distant doc. Good luck to you and your wife. Nancy
Posts.Title: Hello all, and advice needed NancysHubby NancysHubby

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2008 12:13PM RetrieverMomNancy wrote: Denise, Check to see if your insurance company has an advocate program. Mine (Principal) does and with her help I just had a PET covered. Two prior during my orginal dx and treatment last year were denied, even after multiple appeals. I started at stage IIIc with a "hot" node near the collarbone that showed up on the 1st PET, but they said payment wasn't impacted by the details uncovered. A jump in my TM tests this Sept. led to another PET that showed bone mets to the spine. Maybe the good news of being a stage VI lady is that the insurance companies will cover more dignostic tests, so we can all stay ahead of the curb! My heart goes out to you for the loss of your brother, but please remember, we all have our own path to follow. You have the chance to live many, many productive years with or without your hair. Good luck to you.

Good luck and I hope it helps. I hope you can focus on getting better, not how you're going to pay the bills! Nancy

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2009 04:49PM RetrieverMomNancy wrote: Kim, For me the hardest part of the bc journey is waiting for test results. I wish you the best and hope your scan results are excellent. My mets to the spine were identified by a PET scan that was ordered because my TM levels were elevated. It was four months after my original tx ended and I didn't have any symptoms. I didn't "catch it early" with my original dx, but my onc and I try to identify changes as early as possible now. Come to the boards for help getting through chemo! There are a lot of great suggestions that will help you get through treatment. Good luck to you. Nancy

Posts.Content: May 4, 2010 06:10PM retrievermom wrote: Add vitamin E oil to the list.  And xclair and biofine. I was told that natural aloe from the plant was, by far, the best thing to use, so I'm harvesting a plant. I also like the utterly smooth. Nothing with petroleum in it, or a drying agent like alcohol.  I was told the thing about perfumes was that they may contain a metal base that could interfere with the radiation.

Posts.Title: Frightening NYT article on radiation TX pj12 MAGOB

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2013 08:56AM RetrieverMomNancy wrote: I'll bet your TMJ is more related to the stress of stage iv bc than Zometa infusions. I've had tmj for many years and my dentist says it doesn't make me more or less susceptible to ONJ. If I go without my night guard for a few nights I'll start having popping and clicking. I've been on Zometa for five years, mainly monthly, but recently we started to spread infusions out to every three months. My understanding is that Zometa stays I your system a LONG time, so I don't think taking a short break will help. Give a night guard a try.
Posts.Title: Zometa and TMJ Barb312 PaulAndSandy

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2011 07:34AM RetrieverMomNancy wrote: Lilredpony - I'm sorry you have to join this club, but I'm glad you found this forum. Where are your mets? Why are you on pain killers - I know it's because you're in pain, but I'm asking where, to see if there are other possible remedies. I'm four years out from a stage IV dx and I live a pretty normal, full life. My onc and I talk about the ways to manage this disease for the next 10 to 20 years. (I'm 55) There are a lot of chemo options for you. The trick is managing the side effects from all of the drugs! Our stress level goes through the roof whenever it's time for a scan or change of treatment, but in between there can be many normal days. Please, take advantage of those times to do things that bring joy into your life. Sounds like grandbabies could be a wonderful "distraction"! Nancy
Posts.Title: Im a newby and scared lilredpony DivineMrsM
